results.title: Privilege
results.brief_description: A pre-eminenent feminist experimental filmmaker and performer, Yvonne Rainer has been making films since the seventies. Her work utilises a variety of art and media forms to create a multi-layered series of images and texts that convey her deep interest in human relationships. “Privilege” is a reflexive narrative which employs found and staged interviews, fragments of drama and graphic inserts on a computer screen to disjunctively range over the themes of menopause, racism and rape, from which the viewer is required to distil meaning on the issues of sexual and class identity. Cast includes Alice Spirak and Blaire Baron.

results.title: Privates on parade
results.creator_credit: Hand Made Films, Simon Relph and Michael Blakemore
results.brief_description: To fight the good fight, British soldiers in Southeast Asia will need to laugh the good laugh. That’s where Major Giles Flack (John Cleese) and his morale-boosting theatrical troup led by the gloriously high-camp Acting Captain Terri Dennis (Denis Quilley) come in. The war and the show must go on! A farcical musical comedy underscored by the realities of war. Screenplay and lyrics by Peter Nichols based on his own play “Privates on parade”, music composed and conducted by Denis King. Cast also includes Nicola Pagett, Patrick Pearson, Joe Melia, Simon Jones, Michael Elphick, John Standing. Executive producer - George Harrison (Beatles). Contains b&w scenes.

results.title: Private life of the Kingfisher
results.creator_credit: BBC-TV, Jeffery Boswall and Ronald and Rosemary Eastman
results.brief_description: A most intimate and detailed study of the Kingfisher, one of Britain’s most brilliant birds - it has a dazzling cobalt blue back, bright orange under parts, and scarlet feet. Follows the fortunes of a pair of birds through the year. They are shown in sunshine and snow, above water and below, and around their nest hole. Narrated by Peter Scott.

results.title: Private life of a silkworm
results.brief_description: Covers all phases in the production of natural silk; close-ups of silkworm feeding on mulberry leaves; spinning cocoon; mechanical separation of males and females; mating and laying of eggs; removal of silk from cocoons; spinning of individual strands into a thread; weighing and checking hanks; weaving of silk cloth.

results.title: Private life of a cat
results.brief_description: The animal’s outlook on life. The camera lens has been treated as the eyes of a mother cat, observing the daily details of life in a feline family. Thus, an ordinary room becomes an immense foreign environment, in which is enacted the drama of birth - a sequence now celebrated as one of the the most unusual in film literature.

results.title: Private John Simpson
results.creator_credit: Film Australia, Ron Saunders, Pamela Vanneck and Henri Safran
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Willesee’s Australians”.
One of the greatest symbols of Australia at war is that of Private John Simpson and the Battle of Gallipoli. Simpson and his donkey “Duffy” were a familiar sight on the shores of Gallipoli as they worked day and night carrying wounded allied soldiers from the frontline to the beach. He was attributed with saving the lives of hundreds, his tenderness and concern for the wounded were renowned. His death was inevitable and he knew it. Private John Simpson and his donkey have gone down in history as a bastion of valour amidst a world at war.

results.title: Private Benjamin
results.creator_credit: Warner Bros Pictures, Nancy Meyers, Charles Shyer, Harvey Miller and Howard Zieff
results.brief_description: Private Benjamin is a pampered upper-middle-class Judy Benjamin, widowed on her wedding night. She enlists for a three-year, all-expenses-paid sojourn in the U.S Army, or so she was informed by a persuasive recruiter while trying to decide what to do with her life. With such unrealistic expectations, the results can only be disastrously funny - and they are - in this now-classic tale of a fish-out-of-water coming of age via the rigors of basic training and European adventures that test her new independence.

results.title: Private and confidential
results.creator_credit: Swinburne Institute of Technology. Film and Television School and Joe Bogdanov
results.brief_description: It was the first time a boy had kissed me. I felt as though I was reeling, soaring drowning-all at once, I gave myself completely to his lips! So thinks the teenage heroine of this in-depth look at True Romance Comix. The stage is set for Joan’s undoing. Useful for exploring popular culture, sexism and melodrama. Winner, Diploma of Merit, Melbourne Film Festival, 1984.

results.title: Privacy
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “The State of the Nation Bounds of Freedom”.
A journalist comes across certain documents which could be embarrassing - or worse - to a public figure. Should he disclose the contents of these papers? Moderated by Arthur Miller.

group.title: The State of the Nation Bounds of Freedom

results.title: Prisoners of propaganda
results.brief_description: In 1943, the Imperial Japanese Army Secret Service forced a group of Australian servicemen to appear in a film to show the “exemplary” conditions under which Prisoners of War were treated by Japan. This program looks at the mysterious story behind that film, titled, Calling Australia.
